title.narrative: Rule of Law Partnership in Uzb

description.narrative: Building public trust and achieve greater alignment with internationally recognized standards of civil court’s accountability, rule of law and judicial performance.

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: 1.1. Availability of research mechanism for survey of public’s satisfaction level of courts’ activities. 1.2. Percent of judges and court staff, trained on issues of Ethics Code of judges adoption. 1.3. Availability of Communications Strategy on increasing awareness of public, society and media about courts’ activities. 1.4. Availability of Concept on mechanisms to provide free legal aid during civil cases. 1.5. Number of proposals on further support of judicial reforms, developed with the participation of representatives of expert community, lawyers and international donor organizations and submitted for consideration to Supreme court of the Republic of Uzbekistan. 1.6. Availability of amendments to normative legal act on enforcement of court decisions with a view to ensure effectiveness of bailiffs’ activities. 2.1. Number of practical manuals and new courses on actual issues of civil justice for judges, court staff and the public. 2.2. Availability of draft strategy for continuous education of civil courts and judicial staff designed and submitted to national partners for consideration. 2.3. Availability of draft qualifications requirements to the civil court secretaries formulated and submitted to Supreme Court and other beneficiaries. 2.4. Availability of methodological framework for application of international conventions in courts. 3.1. Number of analytical papers and materials on issues of further enhancement of procedural legislation. 3.2. Number of users of “E-SUD” information system, (disaggregated by user profile, types of cases, and instances) 3.3. Availability of normative framework to allow parties to the commercial disputes enjoying the benefits of system of audio-video recording during litigation and appeal process.

comment.narrative: 1.1. Institutional feedback mechanisms for citizens are needed further improvement. 1.2. Ethics Code of judges, developed and approved in 2013, is not accessible for wider public and needed supplementary regulation on procedural issues. 1.3. Enhancement of legislation of the Republic of Uzbekistan in the area of government transparency and accessibility of information about public authority activities, as well as the principle of trial publicity, require from court system development of strategic and regulating documents, aimed at further improvement of situation in this area and increasing public trust. 1.4. Now existing mechanisms of providing free legal aid are implemented in the framework of criminal justice and not applied to civil courts. 1.5. Experts community, lawyers, advocates, international donor organizations, representatives of public and other stakeholders are not involved in discussion of realization of judicial reforms and development of proposals for their further improvement and enhancement. 1.6. Enforcement of court rulings is a cornerstone, influencing on the level of public trust in courts. According to Decree of President of the Republic of Uzbekistan # ??-722 dated 01.11.2007, on results of nine months of 2007 about 20% enforcement orders have not been enforced and about 25% enforcement orders have been enforced with missed deadlines, fixed by legislation. This fact is attributed with both high workload of enforcement officers, and gaps in legislation regulating enforcement process. 2.1. Mechanisms of professional development of judges and court staff, including development of their professional and technical skills, are needed further enhancement. 2.2. Despite there is national legislation on legal education, however, continuous legal education of practitioners is fragmented throughout different agency-based training institutions. A comprehensive agenda setting is this regard is needed. 2.3. Acting judges and court staff are not enough invo

1. Analytical report with proposals on improving the mechanism of appointing judges 2. Analytical report on the best practices for performance assessment of courts and judges 3. Analytical report on the best international practices on court administration 4. 1 analytical paper with proposals on further enhancement of criminal and criminal procedural legislation, 2 analytical papers with proposals on further enhancement of civil and civil procedural legislation, 1 analytical paper with proposals on further enhancement of Code of proceedings in administrative courts 5. 2 comparative analyses of the best international practices of ensuring right to a fair trial with national legislation 6. 150 individuals have access to formal justice (disaggregated by gender and vulnerable groups) including: A) through free legal aid mechanisms; B) through interactive services of courts. 7. 2 training courses elaborated based on results of needs assessment of judges and court personnel 8. i) 550 000 applications submitted (processed) to courts through the E-SUD (sex-disaggregated); (ii) 2 interactive services of electronic judicial systems. 9. 16 courts and 1600 participants (sex-disaggregated) in the judicial system who participated in a survey on satisfaction with court

1.1. The project has prepared the analytical paper on national mechanisms for appointing judges, reappointing judges to new terms, as well as disciplinary actions against judges. The analyses of the existing mechanisms allowed for identifying several bottlenecks in the mechanism of: - Appointing judges for the first tenure, including unclear mechanisms of handling the applications and need for attaching unnecessary documents to application, duplicated checks of the background of the candidate to judge positions, several (and ineffective) examinations were taken by candidates prior to being appointed as a judge, and other situations. - Appointing judges for the second and consequent tenures, including dependence on recommendations need to be provided by the chairperson of the court, reporting on judge activities which includes the number of abolished cases during first term, the need for filing documents which had been filed when applying to judge position for the first time, vague criteria for the promotion of judges, and other situations. - Disciplinary actions against judges, including a lack of review mechanisms of decisions on the disciplinary actions of judges, bringing judges to disciplinary responsibility on the basis of private definitions issued against them, a wide range of grounds for disciplinary actions against judges, duplicated functions between the Supreme Judicial Council and the qualification commission of judges, and other situations. Recommendation reflected in the paper regarding a) the need for defining and establishing an objective criteria for the evaluation of judges, b) the wide introduction of ICT tools in the judicial selection process, as well as the publication of the results of selection on the website, and c) the need to develop objective criteria for selecting judges. The first two recommendations were reflected in paragraph 15 of the State Anti-Corruption Programme 2019-2020 (Decree of the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan #УП-5729 signed on May 27th 2019). The third recommendation was reflected by Mr. Diego García-Sayán, the Special Rapporteur on the independence of judges and lawyers during his press conference, where he shared his preliminary findings as a result of his official visit to Uzbekistan. The project worked with UNDP to contribute more to the recommendations made by the Special Rapporteur regarding the independence of judges and lawyers
1.2. Project has finalized analytical paper on ‘Measuring judicial efficiency’. The paper provides detailed overview of the existing mechanisms of measuring judicial efficiency including the indicators that are used for this purpose. Analyses showed that there are number of issues in the existing mechanism of evaluating efficiency of judges. These include: a) the existing mechanism of measuring judicial efficiency aims to evaluate efficiency of judge whereas similar mechanisms in foreign countries aim to measure efficiency of courts, since measuring efficiency of judges can negatively affect independence of judges; b) number of indicators for measuring efficiency of judges are very subjective and can be ill-treated by those who participate in measuring efficiency of judges. For instance one of the sub-indicators aims to measure the quality of court decisions (grammatical, lexical, mistakes and typos) by the member of the regional qualification commission members who are in almost all cases are lawyers and not philologists, therefore their qualification to analyze the quality of court decisions (grammatical, lexical, mistakes and typos) is questionable. Another similar sub-indicator is composition of court decisions in a clear and precise language. This indicator aims to measure the level of ‘understandability’ of court decisions to parties. However, this kind of measurement require availability of some methodology, which is not in place for Uzbek language, or require availability of systemic citizen feedback mechanism on understandability of court decisions; c) indicator related to ‘monitoring the enforcement of court decisions by judge’ is not relevant since judges lack authority to monitor the enforcement procedures. Based on the analyses as well as brief overview of experience of foreign countries number of proposals are reflected in the paper. These include a) the methodology should be revised to measure efficiency of courts not judges to avoid negative impact on personal independence of judges, b) indicators as well as procedures to measure indicators should be renewed with wide usage of ICT tools, etc. The paper ‘Measuring judicial efficiency’ with recommendations and brief overview of foreign experience was submitted to Supreme Court for consideration.
1.3. Availability of comparative analysis of national and best international practice on established mechanisms of judicial planning, court administration and budgeting. The Project has conducted an analysis of the legislation of Canada, France and Spain on court administration and budgeting, as well as court budgeting system of Uzbekistan. Analyses showed that there are number of issues in the existing mechanism of evaluating court budgeting system. These include: a) budget planning is mostly done annually, there are no long term plans, as well as there is no concept for the development of court budgeting system; b) the research of the specific good for the judicial system (e.g. special equipment, furniture, etc.) is not conducted, the items are mostly low cost and not enough quality; c) judicial system has a great shortage of financial provision, which includes everything (from salaries to paper); d) court budgets are not transparent, it is not published and discussed publicly; e) there is a lack of e-tools on court budgeting system. The research also includes some recommendations to improve the financial system: - Modernize drafting of judicial statistics - Establish a legal framework for the dialogue of budget planning - Strengthen coordination among central government, peripheral delegations of Department on provision of court activities and Chiefs Judges - Foster the use of computer internal platforms, intranet or videoconferencing - Establishment of a multi-year public finance programming strategy - Setting up a department or task force specifically dedicated to the development of cross-agency studies - Establish joint procurement committees composed of different stakeholders to ensure the management dialogue to set inter-departmental committees with regular meetings for assessing future needs and design strategies. - Gradually explore public-private partnerships beginning by limited projects, etc. Moreover, on December 10th the Project has held an international round table aimed at wide discussion court budgeting system and consequently work out the list of relevant recommendations. Overall court budgeting system of Uzbekistan has not been thoroughly studied before, the research of court financing in Canada, France and Spain includes the experience of different court budgeting systems (centralized, not centralized and mixed one) which allows reader compare various systems. These research is aimed at identification of measures to be taken in order to optimize court budgeting system, create beneficial base for judiciary which as a result will help to fight corruption, stimulate women be involved in the judicial system, increase the quantity of highly qualified staff, and considerably increase the quality of judicial acts. The recommendations identified during the international round table will focus on digitalization of court budgeting, optimizing expenses, financing.
1.4. During the reporting period, the project finalized several analytical products within all spheres of judicial legislation. Analytical paper ‘Comparative analysis of measures to introduce alternatives to detention’ The analysis includes description of actuality of the problems, causing incorrect application of detention, legislation analysis, explanation, why alternatives for detention are to be applied and how to improve acting measures in this sphere. The analysis showed that the low level of application of alternatives for detention is caused most of all either by the high efficiency of detention necessity justification by bodies of preliminary investigation that the courts have no legal grounds to refuse them, or inadmissible negligence of the courts in considering applications for the election of a preventive measure in the form of detention. Supporting with a brief analysis of best foreign practices the following recommendations were developed: - to fix in the Criminal Procedural Code the duty of the judge in the election of a preventive measure in the form of detention to find out whether there are sufficient data to charge the suspect or the accused, or the nomination against him suspicion of the fact of committing a crime. - to revise the construction of article 236 of the Criminal Procedural Code, which directly contributes to the incorrect practice of electing this type of preventive measure. - to introduce additional criteria for the election and application of preventive measures in the form of detention. - to give to a judge the right to examine the evidence and guilt of a suspect or accused of a likely crime would provide a mandatory test of the validity of the charge or suspicion, as well as the qualification of the alleged acts. - to amend article 243 of the Criminal Procedural Code in accordance with which, when considering the election of a preventive measure in respect of a suspect or accused in the form of detention, the judge will check the availability of sufficient data to charge a person or raise suspicion of committing a crime, as well as checking the correctness of the qualification of the act by this person. - to amend the seventh part of article 243 of the Criminal Procedural Code, providing for the mandatory participation of the defender in the procedure of consideration by the court of the petition for election of a preventive measure in the form of detention, thereby ensuring the implementation of the principle of equality and competitiveness of the parties in real practice. - to extent the rights of the defender in the procedure of consideration by the court of the petition for election of a measure of restraint in the form of detention, including the right to invite persons to the court session for questioning by the court of circumstances important for making the right decision. - to legislate a list of diseases in the presence of which the detention of suspects and accused persons is not allowed. - to recommend the Supreme School for Judges of the Republic of Uzbekistan to develop a special technique for judges to review motions to remand in custody and on the basis of this technique is to intensively train judges in criminal cases. - to determine in article 250 of the Criminal Procedural Code specific grounds for the application or non-application of preventive measures, including providing for a specific procedure for determining the duration of its validity, extension and other conditions of its application. - to amend article 242-1 of the Criminal Procedure Code of the Republic of Uzbekistan with the list of persons to whom house arrest may be applied, including persons older than 60 years, people with disabilities of group I, pregnant women and women with children under the age of eight years, as well as those accused of committing a particularly serious crime. - to amend the Regulation “On the procedure for applying a preventive measure in the form of house arrest”. - to establish mechanism of identification of pledge sum. This analytical research is transferred to the Supreme Court to working group on Criminal Procedural Code for taking into account into preparation of its new edition.
Analytical paper ‘Comparative analysis of measures to introduce alternatives to the punishment of imprisonment’ The paper includes analysis of acting legislation in sphere of imprisonment application as well as statistics analysis and comparative analysis of Uzbekistan legislation with best foreign practices on each alternative of imprisonment. The main recommendations developed in the paper are: - To expand the list of socially dangerous acts punishable by a fine. - to amend the national legislation the legal institution fine per days, which will assign the penalty of fine in daily rates, the calculation of which the court will take into account the income which has or may have on an average day - to provide possibility of stimulation of behavior of the condemned on penalty execution by granting delays and installments of its payment, as well as the possibility of reducing the size of the fine or even exemption from further execution, subject to compensation for the damage caused by the crime. - to increase the limits of the sanction of this punishment by increasing the maximum term from four hundred and eighty hours to a thousand hours. - to amend national legislation in order to reduce court time or early release from compulsory public works for reporting Inspection for execution of punishments of the internal affairs bodies or the request of the convicted conscientious practicing them at least half of the assigned hours. - Combining the punishments of compulsory community service and correctional labor into one punishment, which will lead to the practice of imposing punishment in the form of correctional labor in two types: - correctional work at the place of main work; - free correctional labor in other places determined by the court. This analytical paper is transferred to the Supreme Court to working group on Criminal Procedural Code for taking into account into preparation of its new edition.
Analytical paper ‘Problems of administrative justice of the Republic of Uzbekistan’ includes: - Analysis of the current situation in the Republic of Uzbekistan - Statistics of administrative courts - Analysis of foreign experience on some issues of administrative justice question of jurisdiction - Issues of execution of decisions of the administrative court - Issues of participation of the Prosecutor in administrative cases - Issues of different approaches to understanding administrative justice - Current legislation on administrative justice in the Republic of Uzbekistan: problems and their justification - Issues of theoretical and legislative fixing of signs of the administrative act - Participation of the Prosecutor in administrative proceedings of the Republic of Uzbekistan - Issues of execution of court decisions in the Republic of Uzbekistan - Issues of jurisdiction of administrative courts in the Republic of Uzbekistan Final recommendations of the paper include the following: 1. To guarantee efficiently and efficiently working of administrative justice by supporting a high level of qualification and professionalism of the judiciary and other employees of administrative justice, attention should be drawn to the personnel policy in the system of administrative courts and emphasis should be placed on the question of the independence of judges from any outside influence and interference in decision-making. A training programme for administrative judges should be developed. 2. To amend the Code of administrative procedure of the Republic of Uzbekistan on refusal of participation of the Prosecutor in the consideration of disputes arising from public legal relations. 3. To develop mechanisms, i.e. legal procedures, ensuring the implementation of the principle of justice in the form of restoration of violated rights or providing compensation when making illegal decisions by public authorities. In addition, based on the positive experience of foreign practice, it is proposed to refer these categories of cases directly to the consideration of administrative courts. 4. New definition and features of administrative act are to be fixed in the legislation. 5.To develop and implement methods of influence aimed at timely execution of judicial acts of administrative courts on the basis of foreign experience. The results of the research will be used during development of concepts of new editions of Code of Administrative Justice and Administrative Offences Code, which is to be developed in 2020.
1.5. The project has prepared following comparative analyses of the best international practices: - ‘Budget Planning and Financing of Court Activities: overview of foreign experience’; - ‘Development of Administrative Justice in Foreign Countries’; - ‘Review of foreign experience in resolving the disputes which arise from administrative matters and public legal relations (France, Canada, the U.S., Russia, Spain, Switzerland, The Netherlands, Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia, Ukraine, Moldova, and other European countries); - ‘Overview of foreign BAR models’; - Overview of experience of South Korea in developing mediation courts with focus on the current state of art of the mediation and plans for further development as well as factors that lead to successful implementation of mediation in these countries - Overview of experiences of Singapore in developing mediation courts with focus on the current state of art of the mediation and plans for further development as well as factors that lead to successful implementation of mediation in these countries - Overview of experiences of Russian Federation in developing mediation courts with focus on the current state of art of the mediation and plans for further development as well as factors that lead to successful implementation of mediation in these countries - Overview of experiences of Kazakhstan Republic in developing mediation courts with focus on the current state of art of the mediation and plans for further development as well as factors that lead to successful implementation of mediation in these countries; - Overview ‘Court-media interaction: Lessons Learned from the Slovak Republic, Slovenia, Estonia, Australia and South Korea’; - Review of best foreign practices on administrative justice with focus for organization and functioning of administrative courts in the USA, Canada, European and Baltic countries, Moldova and Ukraine; - Review of best foreign practices of South Korea, Canada, Hungary, India, Estonia, the Fillipines, New Zeland, Japan, Singapore, the USA, Great Britain, Russia, France and Italy on institutional and functional issues of judicial competence-based education organization.
1.6. 540 (40% women) individuals accessed to formal justice through free legal aid mechanisms. 3 041 legal entities, 17 408 individuals and 706 lawyers accessed to formal justice through interactive services of courts; Those, who get free legal aid in legal clinics, include: - single mothers (15%) - retirees (15%) - unemployed (30%) - people with disabilities (10%) - others (30%)
1.7. Project has developed following training materials and courses including: - Training of trainers for Supreme School of Justice; - Training on application of judges educational needs assessment methodology; - Training on work with written and material evidences, experts’ conclusions, testimonies and other types of evidences by judges in civil procedure; - Training of stress management for judges; - Training on psychology of communication for judges.
1.8. From01.01.2018 to 04.12.2019 more than 500 thousand applications and more than 476 thousand petitions submitted (processed) to courts of civil cases through E-SUD system. 5 interactive services of electronic judicial systems were elaborated.
1.9. The project has also developed infographics and posters, which inform the greater public about key legal reforms, laws and court activities impacting citizens’ lives, such as ‘Benefits of Mediation?’, ‘E-SUD impacts’, ‘International standards for lawyers’ as well as quarterly, half year and 9 months infographics on administrative, criminal, civil and economic courts’ activities in 2019 (in total 8 infographics and posters).
1.10. The project has developed methodology of survey conduction including description of methodology, questionnaires for judges, advocates, prosecutors, judicial staff, legal academic society and participants of court trials, and methodology of collected date analysis. The project has conducted piloting survey for verification of questionnaires within administrative, criminal, civil and economic courts of district, Tashkent city level and in the Supreme Court. In each court at least 3 judges and 3 court staff members were involved into piloting. About 15 advocates and 10 members of academic society participated in piloting procedure. The project also prepared cost-assessment for conduction of the survey and initiated the negotiations with national partner on conduction of survey in 2020.

Output Indicator 4: Number of analytical papers with proposals on further enhancement of: i) criminal and criminal procedural legislation; ii) civil and civil procedural legislation; iii) Code of proceedings in administrative courts Target for 2020: i) 0; ii) 0; iii) 1
Output Indicator 5: Number of comparative analyses of the best international practices of ensuring right to a fair trial with national legislation Target for 2020: 1
Output Indicator 7: Number of training courses elaborated based on results of needs assessment of judges and court personnel Target for 2020: 2
Output Indicator 8: Number of: i) applications submitted (processed) to courts through the E-SUD (sex-disaggregated); (ii) Interactive services of electronic judicial systems. Target for 2020: i) 250 000 ii) 0
Output Indicator 9: Number of published statistics (sex-disaggregated as applicable) on court activities. Target for 2020: Analytical report on justice related indicators related to SDGs 16.
Output Indicator 10: Number of: (i) courts and ii) participants (sex-disaggregated) in the judicial system who participated in a survey on satisfaction with court activities Target for 2020: i) 16 ii) 1600

1.2. Project has finalized analytical paper on ‘Overview of Foreign Experience on Increasing Womens Representation in the Judiciary’. This paper contains an overview of gender parity in the judiciaries of foreign countries, along with recommendations for improving the representation of women at Uzbekistan’s courts. Recommendations include: a) Bridging the gender gap in legal education by increasing numbers of female students at law schools; b) Including systematic gender training and gender sensitivity training for students at law schools; c) Increasing the representation of women in other legal professions and structures from which judge candidates are recruited and a pool of judges is formed; d) Conducting a proactive campaign to engage female lawyers; e) Improving the activities of selection commissions by ensuring gender diversity in their composition and amending regulations of the commission, according to which one of the tasks of the commission is to achieve gender balance in courts; f) Improving working conditions in order to increase the attractiveness of the judge profession for women; g) Creating a platform for discussing the representation of women in courts in the form of conferences and roundtables, dialogues or publications in editions of the Supreme Court’s online newsletters, the creation of a forum or association of women judges, and the creation of a women’s wing in the Association of Judges of Uzbekistan (similar to the women’s wings of political parties); h) Developing a Supreme Court gender strategy to increase the number of women judges, or a related roadmap, in order to ensure the involvement of more women in the judiciary, including in leadership positions; i) Ensuring gender balance in the composition of commissions for the selection and appointment of judges; j) Introducing a 30% gender quota for judge candidates, similar to the parliamentary quota; k) Ensuring that gender issues are considered in the appointment of judges, and in codes of ethics; l) Ensuring the collection of data for monitoring and developing indicators, both qualitative and quantitative, in order to monitor the situation regarding women’s representation at courts; m) Conducting trainings for judges on gender issues, reflecting international documents on equal rights of men and women, best practices for increasing the representation of women in courts, best practices for ensuring access to justice for women (especially in regards to handling cases of gender discrimination or gender-based violence), and other matters. Project has finalized analytical paper on ‘Improving Women’s Access to the Judiciary: Best World Experience and National Practice’. This publication is devoted to the issues of best practice in ensuring womens access to justice, as well as the problems and barriers women face when applying to courts in cases when their rights have been violated. Along with the justification of the need to implement international best practices, issues of determining most effective measures for ensuring access to justice for women have also been reviewed. a) Based on best practices, the following measures have been developed as recommendations for implementation in Uzbekistan: b) Adopting roadmaps and other laws to concretize norms of two gender laws adopted in 2019, through which the judicial protection of women is considered a crucial part of law; c) Conducting training for judges, lawyers, and staff of centers of assistance of social rehabilitation and adaptation, regarding domestic violence and gender issues in general; d) Developing and implementing gender indicators in the judiciary, in particular taking into account Section 16 of the Law ‘On the Protection of Women from Harassment and Violence’, which states that indicators such as the number of cases considered by a court on domestic violence and the number of related convictions should be regularly tracked and monitored; e) Developing a free legal aid system and creating more legal clinics on gender issues (including online clinics), increasing the number of helplines, and forming an electronic database and electronic directories of womens NGOs that provide such assistance; f) The adoption of two gender laws necessitates training judges on gender issues, and therefore the development of special training courses for judges, including online courses on gender equality and domestic violence. Their development should particularly take digitalization processes into account. It is also important to comment on laws on gender equality and violence against women, while providing guidelines through which judges can consider such categories of cases; g) The creation of specialized courts on issues of gender equality and violence is impractical, due to the financial costs of establishing these separate courts, and the adoption of such measures should be proportionate to the degree and level of violence. Instead it is advisable to create helplines and online consultations with courts on these issues, as well as to introduce relevant sections onto the websites of judicial structures. Project has finalized analytical paper on ‘Development and Implementation of Gender Indicators for Evaluating the Effectiveness of the Activities of Judicial Authorities within the Field of Ensuring and Protecting Women’ (Annex 3). This paper contains an overview of qualitative and quantitative gender indicators in the judiciary, and also recommendations for implementing new gender indicators in the judiciary system. The recommendations include legislative, institutional and programmatic strategies, and the suggestion of 26 new indicators for further implementation in Uzbekistan’s and ‘On the Protection of Women from Oppression and Violence’, have created provisions on gender statistics and gender indicators, as well as the right to appeal to the court in cases when provisions of laws are violated. The development of gender indicators within the field of justice will contribute to the concretization and implementation of the provisions of these laws.
1.4. In order to enhance the procedural independence of judges, the project working together with the Supreme Court to published, with the approval of this national partner, the following studies on best foreign practices within judicial activities: • Methodological toolkit (recommendations) on the evaluation of written evidence in criminal proceedings. • Review of Experiences of Foreign Administrative Courts in Resolving Administrative Cases and Public-Legal Disputes • Methodological toolkit (methodology) ‘Interviewing parties in civil proceedings’. • E-version of an Overview of foreign experience on procedures for obtaining, submitting of various evidence in civil proceeding by advocates • E-version of an Overview of foreign experience on procedures for obtaining, submitting of various evidence in criminal proceeding by advocates • E-version of an Overview of foreign experience on accessing various evidence in civil proceeding by judges • E-version of an Overview of foreign experience on procedures of accessing various evidence in criminal proceeding by judges • Manual on psychological trainings for judges In order to continue providing support in strengthening the systemic independence of administrative courts, the project has prepared and posted online e-versions of the analytical paper ‘Problems of Administrative Legal Proceedings in Uzbekistan’ (Annex 11). At the same time the project is preparing for publication the ‘Review of the Experiences of Foreign Administrative Courts in Resolving Administrative Cases and Public-Legal Disputes (covering Baltic countries, Ukraine, Moldova, France, Spain, the USA, Canada, Russia, Switzerland, the Netherlands, Germany and Austria). The review’s printing has been postponed to the next quarter due to the COVID-19 pandemic. In order to continue providing support for strengthening the systemic independence of administrative courts, the project has prepared close-to-final drafts of concepts on further improving the Code of Administrative Justice and the Code on Administrative Offence. The draft concept on further improving of the Code of Administrative Justice underlines the need for solutions of several conceptual problems. These include the need for clear identification of administrative courts’ jurisdictions; legal fixation of administrative proceedings definitions; jurisdiction on some categories of disputes; lack of special principles of administrative proceedings; lack of legal regulation of the legal status of administrative proceeding participants; and procedural mis-regulations on administrative court appeals, settlement agreement in administrative proceedings, and execution of acts of administrative courts. It also covers proposals of solutions for practical problems related to appealing procedures in administrative courts, doubling judicial instances, procedural contradictions among legal norms of different legal acts, regulating the administrative justice sector, and other issues. The draft concept for the further improvement of the Code on Administrative Offences includes proposals on three main types of issues to be solved, specifically those that are conceptual, regulatory and practical. Conceptual issues are related to spheres of definition clarifications, establishment of specific principles, and the institute of exemption of administrative responsibility and rehabilitation of citizens. Regulatory issues cover recommendations for changing the approach to administrative punishment identification and their disproportion with the deal, changing the mechanisms of administrative penalty identification, and addressing gaps within the procedural legal norms of the Code. The procedural amendments are related to an excess of judicial instances acting with administrative offences cases, the development of evidence and proving institute, and the further development of the legal status of advocates and other court participants. In order to support both the individual independence of judges, and the population’s high level of awareness of legal issues, the project has printed the following publications which have been prepared earlier: • A collection of training courses on psychology for judges • Handbook for the population ‘Identifying Elements of Crimes Against Life and Health’ Project has finalized an overview of the experience of 5 top countries on mediation. The best practices of China, Georgia, Germany, Singapore and Kazakhstan have been thoroughly studied, and relevant recommendations have been given. Moreover, the paper contains information about the historical background of mediation in each of the above-mentioned countries, as well as definitions of mediation, types of mediation, measures to support mediation and to motivate people to address it, and various activities regarding the popularization of mediation.
1.5. The project has prepared a proposal on amending provisions within the Judge’s Code of Ethics with gender sensitive elements, to make the Code more gender responsive. The proposal suggests amending three articles, particularly articles 6, 7 and 11. The proposed changes take into account gender aspects of both professional and non-professional activities of judges. They use concepts of direct and indirect discrimination, the content of which is given in the Law of the Republic of Uzbekistan ‘On Guarantees of Equal Rights and Opportunities for Women and Men’, in order to broadly interpret the principle of equality, consider the gender sensitivity of cases involving women, and avoid gender-based inequalities. In Article 6 it is proposed that the provision of the objectivity and impartiality of a judge should be amended to include qualities such as gender sensitivity and the prevention of gender inequality. In Article 7, in accordance with Article 3 of the Law of the Republic of Uzbekistan ‘On Guarantees of Equal Rights and Opportunities for Women and Men’, it is proposed that the forms of discrimination which could be considered direct and indirect discrimination should be clarified. In two cases in Article 11 of the Code (paragraphs 5 and 8), in regards to the powers of chairpersons of courts to indicate the inadmissibility of negative phenomena, it is proposed that gender aspects should be included. An explanatory note with proposals has been submitted to the Supreme Judicial Council for their consideration and further implementation. Also, this note was discussed during the event on ‘The Role of the Judiciary in Ensuring Gender Equality’, held in September 18, 2020. The Project has prepared the research paper Housing Disputes. This paper has been finished and published on the website of the Supreme Court. The paper contains useful information about judicial practices on hearing housing disputes, as well as an analysis of legislative acts in this sphere. It includes information on most common cases, and an analysis of decisions taken by judges. The Project has prepared the paper Visiting Court Sessions. This paper has been finalized and published on the website of the Supreme Court. It paper includes methods for holding visiting court proceedings, an analysis of legislation in this regard, data on visiting court proceedings in 2018 and 2019, and recommendations on improving legislation and practices of organizing visiting court proceedings. The Project has prepared an analytical paper ‘National Mechanisms of Court Budgeting’. The paper has been finished and sent to be published on the web-site of Supreme Court. It includes a brief information on national court budgeting system as well as recommendations of best foreign practices. Moreover it contains an infographic on national court budgeting system. The Project has organized regional practical seminars on international standards of fair trial and the use of the provisions of the UN Human Rights Conventions by national courts in court decisions. The practical seminars have been hold on September 22, 23 and 24 for the judges on administrative, criminal and civil cases of Tashkent city, Tashkent and Sirdarya regions. Practical seminars were organized in a blended format-participants were present offline and international experts made their presentations through zoom. The main part of the trainings included group work on cases. They have covered matters dealing with the unauthorized peaceful assemblies, extraditions of foreign citizens who have served criminal sentences, and gender discrimination. As a result participants were able to use international norm during their group work and got skills of implementing the norms of UN Human Rights Conventions in their decisions. The trainings were organized together with OSCE, Supreme Court and National Human Rights Center of Uzbekistan.
1.7. Due to the level of gender-neutrality of legislation regulating Uzbekistan’s judicial system, as well as by-laws adopted by the Supreme Court, judges and court personnel lack information in terms of both gender issues in the judiciary, and also the ways through which the judiciary can help resolve gender issues. Therefore, the ROL project conducted an event on ‘The Role of the Judiciary in Ensuring Gender Equality’, held on September 18, 2020. The goal of this event was the development of judges understanding of the judiciary’s role in ensuring gender equality, providing a familiarization and review of international standards on women’s rights and gender and justice, and also discussing the roadmap on mainstreaming gender activities into the judiciary. Participants at the practical seminar were able to familiarize themselves with best practices for increasing women’s representation in courts at all levels, improving women’s access to the judiciary, integrating gender indicators in the judiciary, and conducting gender-legal expertise of the legislation of Uzbekistan, all using examples from the ‘Judges’ Code of Ethics’. During group discussions, the judges were able to review a draft of a roadmap on mainstreaming gender activities into the judiciary for 2020-2023, and provide their proposals and recommendations for further developing the roadmap. As part of project activities related to supporting women judges in the judiciary, in addition to helping increase the numbers of women judges and creating a role-model for promoting gender issues in the judiciary, the project has also developed an outreach and media campaign highlighting the abovementioned points. The scenario for this video has been finalized with the video production company, and a related agreement with partners is reached. It is expected that the promotional video will be ready by the end of November. The project has developed three manuals for judges and trainees of the Higher Judicial School on the Step-by-Step Activities of Judges. These manuals are designed to be a handbook for newly-appointed judges and trainees of the Higher Judicial School, covering the daily activities of judges. These three manuals include ‘Step-by-Step Activities of Civil Court Judges’, ‘Step-by-Step Activities of Administrative Court Judges’ and ‘Step-by-Step Activities of Economic Court Judges’. The manuals have been prepared and approved for printing on the interdepartment meeting of ‘Civil law’ and ‘Economic law’ department of Higher Judicial School under Supreme Judicial Council of the Republic of Uzbekistan on August 24, 2020.
1.8. The project published the ‘Annual Report on the Activity of the TSUL Legal Clinic - Y2019’.This report includes gender-desegregated statistics on students, trainers and people who have sought help from the legal clinic. In 2019, 50 students participated in the activity of legal clinic, including 23 female. Total number of cases solved is 540. At the end of 2019 the legal clinic has opened telegram channel and received about 3000 requests to it. The most common issues of requests are labour and pension, inheritance, administrative, family dispoutes and appealing for court acts. The report will be provided to the national partner after the end of the COVID-19 pandemic as the project staff liable is prohibited to visit office now and have no project car for transfer, Two success stories regarding the work of the TSUL Legal Clinic, based on interviews with professors and students working at the clinic, had been developed. The story ‘COVID-19 prepares a new generation of digital lawyers’ posted on the USAID Central Asia website (https://www.usaid.gov/uzbekistan/program-updates/jun-2020-covid-19-prepares-new-generation-digital-lawyers) and on the UNDP Uzbekistan website (https://www.uz.undp.org/content/uzbekistan/en/home/stories/covid-19-prepares-a-new-generation-of-digital-lawyers.html). The second story posted on the UNDP website https://www.uz.undp.org/content/uzbekistan/uz/home/stories/legal-clinic--uzbekistan--undp--rule-of-law-partnership.html. For 2020 total 238 154 applications, including 170 337 claims and 67 817 petitions for issue court orders were registered in E-court information system of the Supreme court of the Republic of Uzbekistan. For the past period the Project ensured reliable and stable functioning E-SUD information system, as well as information resources of the Project, such as incompetent.esud.uz, manuals.esud.uz. Also there weren’t any serious problems and shutdowns on functioning E-SUD information system hardware (servers, switches, etc.) The Project provided consulting for more than 100 internal and external users on operation E-SUD information system, in terms of recovery user account, use digital signature, preparation execution act and send for executive bureaus, checking the state of execution, install E-IMZO and the other applications on PC of users and the other issues.For the reporting period, the Project developed and passed to the Supreme Court more than 120 pages of new design layouts for webpages of E-court information system of the Supreme Court.
1.9. The project has prepared Annual Report 2018-2019 of the Supreme Court of the Republic of Uzbekistan. This report includes information about the main activities of Uzbekistan’s judicial system, as well as important statistical indicators. Moreover, the report’s essential feature is the comparisons it makes with 2018. All data in the report has been compared with indices of the previous year, with percentage decrease or increase being identified. This in many aspects shows the effectiveness of the judicial system’s activities. The project includes gender disaggregated information about the pool of judges, their nationality (which is a recommendation of UN Committees), and the number of convicted and released persons disaggregated by gender. The data analysis on most common disputes in economic, civil and administrative courts have also been included. The report also has data on the execution of judicial acts divided by courts, and contains main news from the judicial sphere. The main goal of the report is to show the results of court activities, to identify progress in various spheres, to fulfill Uzbekistan’s obligations for showing data mentioned in the UN Committee recommendations, and increasing the judicial system’s transparency and popularity. The report has been finished and published in 1000 copies, including 500 in Uzbek, 300 in English, and 200 in Russian. The printed version of the report has been transferred to the Supreme Court, while the e-version has been uploaded to the Supreme Court website.
1.10. The project has launched the process of conducting a Court User’s satisfaction survey, gaining the approval of the national partner, and working on amendments to the questionnaires, which reflect the need for the survey to be conducted online because of the COVID-19 pandemic.
The proposed package of research tools is designed to conduct a comprehensive assessment of the work of grass-roots courts (district\inter-district\city) of General jurisdiction (civil, criminal, administrative courts, economic and military courts). If necessary, after conducting a pilot study, the tools can be used for evaluating courts of General jurisdiction at the regional level.

Output Indicator 2: Availability of a methodology with clear criteria, which inter alia promotes gender balance among judges and court personnel, for assessing the activities of courts in accordance with international standards. Target for 2020: Draft policy document ‘Strategic plan for development of Supreme Judicial Council until 2030’ is developed
Output Indicator 7: Number of training courses elaborated based on results of needs assessment of judges and court personnel Target for 2021: 2
Output Indicator 8: Number of: i) applications submitted (processed) to courts through the E-SUD (sex-disaggregated); (ii) Interactive services of electronic judicial systems. Target for 2021: i) 0 ii) 2
Output Indicator 9: Number of published statistics (sex-disaggregated as applicable) on court activities. Target for 2021: Analytical report on justice related indicators related to SDGs 16.
Output Indicator 10: Number of: (i) courts and ii) participants (sex-disaggregated) in the judicial system who participated in a survey on satisfaction with court activities. Target for 2021: i) 6 ii) 160
